You look around.[/p] [p]You see the knights behind a windmill, with the army's supply wagons. The knights have gone off to eat while they wait for the French to arrive, leaving their helmets to mark their places in the battle order. This army is certainly well organized![/p] [p]You walk along the row of helmets. Soon the helmets are replaced by rows of bows and arrows. This must be where the archers will fight.[/p] [p]A few steps ahead, two men in green clothes drag along what looks like a primitive cannon![/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="94"][/p] [p]“Here, lend us a hand, will you,” one of them calls to you. He looks familiar … yes! It's Tom, the yeoman farmer you met in Winchester in 1357. He told you he was an [em]archer[/em] for the king at Crecy. What is he doing with a cannon?[/p] [p]“Sure, Tom,” you say as you push.[/p] [p]He squints at you. “How are you knowing my name, now?” He doesn't recognize [em]you[/em], of course. It will be eleven years before he meets you in Winchester![/p] [p]“Why, because everybody knows you,” you say. “You're Tom, with the cannon.”[/p] [p]He smiles. “So already we cannoneers are well known, eh? Wait until the battle! King Edward himself wilt come a-thanking us, I don't doubt, for using this new contraption.”[/p] [p]That's a thought. If you stay with Tom and his friends, you might be rewarded by King Edward when the new cannon surprises the French and wins the battle. That would give you a chance to ask the king about the Order of the Garter.[/p] [p]A trumpet sounds. “It's the signal,” shouts Tom. “The French are coming up through the woods!” The knights and archers come running to their places.[/p] [p]Should you stay with Tom or go to where the knights are lining up to fight?[/p]
p.hint: When will they really get a bang out of cannons?

p.text: [p]You're lying on the back of a wooden cart. You can hear the trumpets and screams of the battle of Crecy in the distance. The cannon is gone, but your friend Tom is right next to you.[/p] [p]“I should be getting back to my bow now.” Tom pats you on the shoulder. “Rest quiet. The doctor will be along soon. He'll empty out some of your bad blood, so you'll soon be ready to fight again.”[/p] [p]You have to get out of here. The battle of Crecy may still be the right place to find Edward and become a knight, but it was a mistake to join the cannoneers instead of looking for the knights. You're in France … didn't Lady Joan's friend Sir Walter de Manny come to France to help the Countess of Brittany a couple of years ago?[/p]
p.next: Jump back two years to find Sir Walter de Manny

p.text: [p]You're sitting at a banquet table with Sir Walter and Countess Jannedik. Sir Walter wears a red eyepatch over his left eye.[/p] [p]“My good Sir Walter,” says the countess, “have you hurt your eye?”[/p] [p]Sir Walter kisses her hand. “No, my lady. I have sworn never to take off this eyepatch until I have done a brave deed.”[/p] [p]Countess Jannedik smiles. “You'll get your chance soon enough. But first, let the pipers play!”[/p] [p]Before the music can start, a huge rock comes smashing through the roof. It crashes to the floor, showering the room with dust. Countess Jannedik jumps to her feet. “The French are sending us gifts again,” she says angrily, “with their giant catapult!”[/p] [p]“I'm afraid, madame, that this lovely dinner must wait. We will act at once!” He turns to his men. “We need fifty volunteers. Who will come with me?”[/p] [p]“I shall ride beside you,” cries Countess Jannedik.[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="98"][/p] [p]“We will, too!” shout Sir Walter's knights.[/p] [p]Countess Jannedik takes you aside.[/p] [p]“We will sneak out the back way,” she says, “and attack the catapult from the rear. I want you to wait at the front gate. Open the gate for us when I signal you with my sword. Hurry!”[/p] [p]You run to the front gate. You climb to the top of the tower to watch for the countess's signal.[/p] [p][em]WHAM![/em][/p] [p]The gate shakes beneath you as a huge rock smashes into it. The attackers aim straight for the gate, hoping to smash it down so they can pour their army into the town.[/p] [p]Another crashing blow hits the gate. The iron creaks and bends, but so far it holds firm.[/p] [p]“Look there!” a guard shouts. Off in the distance you can see Sir Walter, the countess, and the fifty volunteers. They gallop along in their battle armor. There are so few of them! What can they hope to do?[/p] [p]Sir Walter tears off his eyepatch and spurs his horse. He shouts a fearsome war cry and rides straight at the army! The French knights are so surprised by this crazy attack, they turn and run away.[/p] [p]Countess Jannedik and the fifty knights rush after him, and in a few minutes they destroy the catapult.[/p] [p]“Hurrah!” shout the guards and archers.[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="100"][/p] [p]The French knights soon come to their senses, though. When they realize how few knights the countess has with her, they turn around.[/p] [p]Countess Jannedik waves her sword at you It's the signal![/p] [p]“Open the gates!” you shout to the guards A horse pulls the rope that draws the gate up.[/p] [p]Sir Walter and Countess Jannedik ride toward you as fast as they can, with a thousand French knights chasing after them. The gate creaks open under you. The raiding party rushes into the town, welcomed by cheers. Now that the catapult has been destroyed, the attack will be easier to defeat.[/p] [p]Uh-oh. The rope holding the gate open is stuck! The gate is wide open for the attacking knights![/p] [p]“Here!” Sir Walter shouts to you. “Use my sword.” You're close enough to cut the rope in time! Sir Walter's sword comes spinning up to you. You have to be careful you don't catch it by the sharp blade![/p] [p]You catch it by the handle and crawl out across a narrow stone ledge. You duck as an arrow whisks past your ear. The rope is still far away! You have to stretch out and swing with the sword …[/p] [p]The rope slices in two. The iron gate falls with a crash, just as the galloping knights are about to ride through.[/p] [p]You reached out too far with the sword though, and lost your balance. You're falling right toward the knights below![/p] [p]It's life or death for you now. Jump in time, quick![/p]
p.next: Travel ahead two years to the battle of Crecy

p.text: [p]You run from the battle toward the part of the army held in reserve. You wonder if you made the right choice. You forgot to deliver the king's message. Not only that, but if part of your mission is to become a knight, why are you running away from danger? Above all, a knight must be brave! An armored fist pinches your shoulder. “What goes on up there?” growls the knight who holds you.[/p] [p]“A few French knights have gotten through, but the prince is fighting them,” you say.[/p] [p]“Did you see a French knight with a blue cross on his shield?”[/p] [p]“No,” you say. You try to pull away from this smelly knight, but he holds you tight.[/p] [p]“Have you heard mention of a knight named Sir Guy?” he growls. His eyes are fierce beneath his hairy face. “Two years ago, I swore a sacred oath. I swore I would never take a bath, nor cut my hair, until I beat that knight!”[/p] [p]You look closer at him. It's Sir Cuthbert, the knight you met at Windsor! He doesn't seem to recognize you. It's hard to recognize him, too - he certainly [em]smells[/em] like it's been two years since he took a bath![/p] [p]“Sorry,” you say. He lets you go. Time to make yourself scarce, you think. If Sir Cuthbert is here, that nasty squire of his must be, too! Should you jump in time? But where? You're in France, where Sir Walter de Manny was supposed to come to aid the Countess of Brittany. Perhaps you could go help him, to prove you're fit to be a knight.[/p] [p]“Aha!” You hear somebody calling you.[/p] [p]Oh no, it's Squire Randall! This time it's not a quarterstaff he is pointing at you but a sharp steel sword![/p] [p]“Who are you, really?” he sneers. “You appear for a few days, then disapppear for years, without a trace! Where do you really come from?”[/p] [p]“I'm from … Navarre,” you say.[/p] [p]“Oh, really?” he says with a smirk. He calls to another squire. “Carlos! You're from Navarre, right? Come here a moment.”[/p] [p]A squire with dark curly hair comes up.[/p] [p]“This creature claims to be from Navarre, too,” says Randall. “Is he?”[/p] [p]Carlos smiles. “A countryman! What a pleasure! How are things back in Pamplona?”[/p] [p]“Uh, fine,” you say.[/p] [p]“How is King Theobald?”[/p] [p]“Well … as well as could be expected.”[/p] [p]Carlos's smile turns into a scowl. “This is a faker, Randall. King Theobald has been dead for years!”[/p] [p]“Oho! So you're not from Navarre, eh?” Randall brings his sword up to rest against your throat. “Is it possible that you're a French spy? Yes! I think so. And in the middle of a war, a spy who's caught can expect no mercy!”[/p] [p]He twists his sword up toward your throat, but you're not about to let him cut your head off! You turn and run.[/p] [p]“Stop the spy!” You race off into the night, as fast as you can run. Randall has more armor on, so he's slower. You duck behind a wagon where no one can see you, and jump in time.[/p]

[p]You say goodbye to Tom and walk behind the archers to the center of the hill, where the English knights wait for the French to attack. King Edward has split his army into three parts, you can see - two at the crest of the hill and one in reserve, in front of an old windmill. The knights line up in battle formation, presenting a row of shields to the enemy. Their squires wait for them behind the lines.[/p] [p]Someone grabs hold of your arm.[/p] [p]“You!” cries a squire wearing a breastplate and metal helmet. “What are you doing here?” He takes his helmet off.[/p] [p]It's your friend, Nigel! He looks older and more confident than he did in the days when he taught you how to be a squire. He should - for him, that was two years ago![/p] [p]“I came to help,” you say.[/p] [p]“Well, you're just in time. Here,” he says excitedly, “I have an extra suit of armor you could wear. You'll need it. The battle is about to begin!”[/p] [p]He stops and looks at you strangely. You try to stand a little taller, as if you were two years older, too.[/p] [p]“By the way,” he says, “where have you been these last two years? We thought you'd gotten lost in the woods! Did you have to go back to Navarre suddenly?”[/p] [p]“Something like that,” you say.[/p] [p]“You shouldn't just disappear like that without telling anyone,” he says, punching you playfully on the shoulder. “But here we are, anyway. Put your helmet on. Here come the arrows!”[/p] [p]You put the helmet on as fast as you can and strap yourself into the breastplate. Putting on your armor helps you feel a little of what it's like to be a knight.[/p] [p]The English longbowmen fire back at the French archers. They send so many arrows flying that the enemy archers turn and run. A wave of French knights charges up the hill, but before they even get halfway up, the arrows cut them down.[/p] [p]“I cannot understand the French battle plan,” Nigel says. “Why attack so late in the day? And why not organize themselves to attack all at once? They send a few knights at a time, to get slaughtered one by one!”[/p] [p]“This is horrible. What is all this fighting for, anyway?” you ask.[/p] [p]Nigel points to the flags fluttering above you.[/p] [p]“There's your answer,” he says. “Both the lilies of France and the leopards of England on King Edward's banners. He believes he should be king of [em]both[/em] England and France.”[/p] [p]“But that's silly,” you say, “England and France are two different countries!”[/p] [p]Nigel stares at you. “Don't say such things!” he whispers. “Evil comes to those who think evil of the king's plans.”[/p] [p]Nigel just said what sounded like the motto of the Order of the Garter! But before you can get him to explain it, you hear a whoosh and a crackling sound behind you. The windmill is in flames![/p] [p]“Our own men set the fire,” says Nigel. “It's getting so dark we can't see to fight without a giant torch.”[/p] [p]You hear loud shouts from the English knights a few feet away. Some of the attackers are getting through! The lead attacker, a French knight on horseback, plunges into the ranks just ahead of you. The attacker swings a long, spiked club, bashing the heads of knights beneath him. He shouts a strange war cry: “Montjoie Saint Denis!”[/p] [p]A young knight with a leopard-covered tunic over his black armor slashes at the French knight with a sword.[/p] [p]“It's Prince Edward!” Nigel shouts.[/p] [p]More French knights make it though the arrows. The prince is in the center of a furious swordfight.[/p] [p]“Curse the day I was born,” mutters Nigel. “Here I stand, doing nothing! Will I ever have a chance to prove I can be a knight?”[/p] [p]“You, squires!” shouts one of the prince's knights. “One of you run to the king. Tell him we need reinforcements!”[/p] [p]You and Nigel look at each other.[/p] [p]“I'll go,” you say. “They may soon need you here.”[/p] [p]“Thank you, my friend!” Nigel says.[/p] [p]You run off toward the burning windmill.[/p] [p]The flames from the burning windmill rise fifty feet in the air.[/p] [p]This may be your chance to ask Edward about the motto![/p] [p]The king stands in front of the burning mill, surveying the bloody battle on the hill below him.[/p] [p]“A message,” you say breathlessly. “The prince needs reinforcements!”[/p] [p]Edward III stares down at you, a grim smile on his lips. “Is my son dead?” he asks quietly.[/p] [p]“No, sire.”[/p] [p]“Has his banner fallen? Or does he still fight on?”[/p] [p]“He still fights,” you say, “but he is well matched.”[/p] [p]The king clasps you by the shoulders. “Tell those who sent you here not to send you again,” he says, “as long as my son is alive. Tell them that my son must have the chance to win his spurs! Go!”[/p] [p]You didn't get a chance to ask the king about the motto of the Order of the Garter. Maybe Nigel had the answer - could the motto have to do with the king's ambition to be king of two countries at once?[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="110"][/p] [p]The prince and his friends are still battling the French knights when you return, but something is missing from the scene. Then you see what it is - the prince's banner has fallen! The official flag carrier is busy dueling with a French knight and has let the banner fall to the ground.[/p] [p]The banner is very important to the knights. Should you rush into the middle of the battle and pick the banner up? Or should you run back to the reserves, where the king is, and try to figure out a way to speak with him again?[/p]
p.next: Go back to the king's reserves
p.hint: A knight must live by the code of chivalry.

p.text: [p]You're standing with Tom by the cannon among a group of English archers. Trumpets sound the call to battle. The archers take their bowstrings out of their helmets, where they keep them dry. They have to pull with all their strength to bend their mighty bows so the strings will fit on them.[/p] [p]“I hope this works,” Tom says as you help him roll a round stone into the fat mouth of the cannon. “It's never been tried in battle before. I'd be much happier with a bow in my hands, but when you're in an army you do what you are told!” So Tom really was an archer![/p] [p]Down below, you see the French army approaching. The army is all spread out and disorganized, but it is far larger than the English forces with you on the hill.[/p] [p]“Look there,” says Tom with surprise. “Archers! I thought the French knights didn't believe in archery.”[/p] [p]“Those are Italian crossbowmen,” an archer says. “They were hired by the French!”[/p] [p]“Ready,” the English archers' commander shouts.[/p] [p]The archers draw back their bows and wait.[/p] [p]“Hyaaagh!” comes a shout from the French army below. Thick, short arrows from the crossbows zip over your head.[/p] [p]“Shoot at will!” shouts the commander. “Stand back,” says Tom. He holds a burning torch in his hand and uses it to set off the cannon.[/p] [p]KABOOM! A huge cloud of smoke erupts from the cannon. The stone, however, just bloops about fifteen feet down the hill and sticks in the ground.[/p] [p]“Bah,” says Tom. “We might as well [em]roll[/em] the stones down the hill!”[/p] [p]It will be a long time, you guess, before battles are won using guns. This is not the way to get King Edward to help you![/p] [p]“I'm going to try it once more,” Tom says, “then I'll get my bow and join the archers, where I belong.”[/p] [p]He puts the torch to the cannon, but nothing happens.[/p] [p]“Watch out,” screams Tom. “It's going to explode!”[/p] [p]You jump for cover, but not fast enough. The last things you see before you lose consciousness are the flash of gunpowder and the ground rushing up to meet you.[/p]

[p]You watch the prince and his knights battle the French knights by the flickering yellow light of the burning mill. The banner lies on the ground, trampled underfoot. You pick up a shield and wait for an opening.[/p] [p]There! The way to the banner is clear. You rush in to pick it up. Just as you reach it, someone else's hand grabs the pole. It's Nigel! You smile at each other as you raise the banner high.[/p] [p]“Hurrah!” cry the fighting knights as they see their banner fly again.[/p] [p]The clink and clank of crossing swords is all around you. From the ground come the the shrieks of the wounded and the groans of the dying.[/p] [p]You hold your shield up as a knight runs at you with his sword. Another knight comes at him from the side and slices off his arm with a battle-ax. The first knight's arm, still holding the sword, falls at your feet.[/p] [p]You look at Nigel. His mouth is set in a tight, brave smile, but his eyes show fear and horror. So [em]this[/em] is the glamorous “sport”, the knights are so very fond of? You prefer the tournaments to this bloody, senseless killing. But knights were warriors, and war is always bloody and cruel.[/p] [p]You're not sure how much more of this you can take. Soon, though, the French knights who got through the lines are all killed or captured.[/p] [p]The prince and his friends stick their swords in the ground and lean on them to rest.[/p] [p]“Where is the messenger we sent to the king?” calls a tall, one-eyed knight.[/p] [p]“Here I am,” you say. Leaving Nigel to hold the banner pole, you walk forward.[/p] [p]“The king told me to tell you,” you say, “not to send for reinforcements unless his son was killed. He said the prince must earn his spurs.”[/p] [p]The one-eyed knight turns to the prince. Blood from a gash on the prince's cheek drips down on his black chain mail.[/p] [p]“Earn his spurs?” says the knight. “I should say the young prince has earned them. He has earned them ten times over!”[/p] [p]“Hurrah for Prince Edward!” shout the knights.[/p] [p]The Black Prince pulls his sword from the ground and walks forward.[/p] [p]“It is not only I who have earned the spurs of knighthood,” he says. “I saw two squires bravely enter the thick of battle to rescue my banner. Kneel, squire!” he commands you.[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="116"][/p] [p]You kneel down in the blood-soaked grass in front of him. The prince holds out his sword. The blade is so nicked and dented by the fighting that it looks like the blade of a saw. He taps the side of the sword on your right shoulder, then your left.[/p] [p]“Arise, knight,” he says. “Be true to your lord, your honor, and your lady fair.”[/p] [p]Then he calls Nigel forward and performs the same ceremony for him.[/p] [p]You've done it! You've been knighted, by the Black Prince himself! Nigel turns to you and smiles, fighting back tears of joy.[/p] [p]The battle goes on late into the night, but finally the French army is defeated. The exhausted English knights lie down to sleep, right in the field of battle.[/p] [p]You still have to find out what the motto of the Order of the Garter means, but now that you're a knight, it should be easier to complete your mission. None of the knights here wear garters on their arms yet. Does it have to do with the king's plans that brought about this battle?[/p] [p]You know that your friend Nigel, now [em]Sir[/em] Nigel, will become a member of the order. The other members could be the knights sleeping all around you, though they may not know it yet.[/p]
p.next: Jump ahead two years to Windsor

p.text: [p]You're back in Windsor, on April 23, 1348. You're standing in the shadows of a courtyard of the castle. A crowd of people watches a long carriage pulled by four black horses enter through the gate. A woman gets out of the carriage, dressed in a beautiful white gown. She goes through a door to a large hall. You can hear music playing inside.[/p] [p]You see a long-haired, frizzy-bearded knight sitting on a block of stone nearby. He looks very sad.[/p] [p]“What is happening?” you ask him.[/p] [p]“The guests are arriving for the king's ball,” he says. “I, too, was invited, but they will not let me in.”[/p] [p]“Why not?”[/p] [p]“Who would want to dance,” he says sadly, “with a poor knight whose last bath was taken four long years ago?”[/p] [p]You look at him. It's Sir Cuthbert! He's the knight who swore never to cut his hair or take a bath until he beat Sir Guy. He's kept his oath, all right. No wonder they won't let him in. He smells terrible![/p] [p]A group of knights dressed in silk and satin arrive on horseback and dismount. You try to follow them in, but a guard blocks your path.[/p] [p]“Only knights and ladies invited by the king are allowed in,” he tells you. “Stand aside!”[/p] [p]He pushes you back with a long spear, sending you sprawling over the cobblestones. People laugh. You pick yourself up and turn to go. You don't care about their stupid ball anyway![/p] [p]“In the name of St. George!” You hear a familiar voice. It's your friend Nigel! [em]Sir[/em] Nigel, now. He stares at you with astonishment.[/p] [p]“We thought you were killed,” he says, “on the battlefield at Crecy!” He turns to the guard and scowls. “This is a hero of Crecy,” he says sternly. “If anyone should be admitted to the king's ball, it should be this noble knight!”[/p] [p]You follow him in to a large hall lined with tapestries and lit with torches. Knights and ladies dance back and forth in long lines. The prince and the king dance with their ladies.[/p] [p]“I don't know how you've come back to us,” Nigel says, “but welcome, welcome! The king has invited all the heroes of Crecy to the tournament tomorrow. But tonight we dance!”[/p] [p]A young woman in a long gown comes up to Nigel. You recognize her - it's Lady Joan of Kent, the one you last saw hunting with falcons. Nigel turns and shrugs to you. He and Joan join the line of dancers.[/p] [p]You sit down at a table near a giant fireplace, across from a knight wearing long, pointed shoes.[/p] [p]“That was Lady Joan, was it not?” he says to you. “Have you heard the latest rumor? She and Prince Edward are in love!”[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="122"][/p] [p]So that's her secret. Joan always said she was in love with a very noble knight - it turns out it's the prince himself![/p] [p]“Why aren't you dancing?” you ask the knight.[/p] [p]He rolls his eyes. “Oh, I don't really feel like it. I'm here as a prisoner, after all. I'm a French knight, captured at the battle of Crecy. Noble prisoners are treated very well - I sit here fighting in tournaments, going to balls, and playing chess. But imagine. It's been two years since I've seen my home in France.”[/p] [p]The music stops and the dancers drift apart. Lady Joan and Nigel stand talking with the king in the middle of the hall. There's something round sitting there on the floor, made of blue cloth. The king bends down to pick it up.[/p] [p]All across the hall, people watch the king and laugh, quietly. What's so funny? You see Lady Joan blushing. It must be a garter he's holding, which was holding up Lady Joan's stocking, but fell off.[/p] [p]“It's the king himself who picks up Lady Joan's garter,” some ladies near you whisper, “but it's really the prince she loves!” The crowd falls silent when they see the king is about to speak.[/p]

[p]“It has been four years,” he says loudly, “since I promised to start a new Round Table of knights, like that of King Arthur. Tomorrow I will choose thirty of my noblest knights to honor above all others.” He waves the garter above his head, “This will be our symbol. [em]Honi soit qui mal y pense[/em]! May evil come to those who think evil of it!”[/p] [p]He signals the musicians, and the dancing starts again.[/p] [p]He's said the famous motto! At last you know where the words come from! The king first uses them to silence whispers about a secret romance, and then gets the idea to use the garter as the symbol of his knights.[/p] [p]“You look disappointed about something,” the French knight says to you. “What's the matter?”[/p] [p]“How would you feel,” you say, “if you went through all sorts of dangers to find something. Then when you found what you were looking for, it wasn't what you thought it was at all?”[/p] [p]He smiles. “That's the way it is with most knightly quests. The knights of the Round Table spent their lives looking for the Holy Grail, but most of them never found it. It doesn't matter so much what you're searching for as much as how you look for it, what you find along the way, and how much you can help the other people searching.”[/p] [p]“Here,” he says, bringing out a leather bag full of chess pieces. “Let's have a game of chess, to take your mind off your troubles.”[/p] [p]“Thanks, Sir … uh …”[/p] [p]“Sir Guy is my name.”[/p] [p]Sir Guy! He's the knight Sir Cuthbert swore he would beat some day. That gives you an idea.[/p] [p]“I don't feel like playing much,” you tell him, “but I have a friend outside who would love to play with you. Come on!”[/p] [p]You take Sir Guy outside, where Sir Cuthbert sits with his head on his hands. Sir Cuthbert is startled to be face to face with his old enemy, but smiles when you whisper your idea in his ear.[/p] [p]The two knights set the pieces up and play. Sir Guy, you can tell, is eager to get the game over with so he can get away from his awfulsmelling opponent. In a short time, the game is over. Sir Cuthbert has won.[/p] [p]“Praise God!” he cries, knocking over the table as he jumps to his feet. “I've won! Now I may take a bath again!” Sir Guy looks at him as if he were crazy. Sir Cuthbert whoops with delight and hugs you with gratitude.[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="124"][/p] [p]You slip out of his arms, and into the shadows of the castle while he dances up and down with glee.[/p] [p]It's too bad, you think as you prepare to jump back to your own time, that the knights didn't learn to solve their disputes with chess instead of war. They still haven't learned that lesson well enough back where you're going, but all the same you're glad to be going back home.[/p] [p]Congratulations! You have reached the end of your quest.[/p]
